sub_subject.name: Ancient Civilizations (Prehistory–500 AD)
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Ancient Civilizations (Prehistory–500 AD) (History & Social Studies)

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Identify Abraham as the father of the family.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Name the Land of Canaan as their new home.
Identify the Great Wall of China.
Name silk as a special cloth from China.
Identify the Terracotta Warriors.
Identify pyramids in the jungle (Maya).
Name corn (maize) as their main food.
Identify the ball game they played.
Identify Assyria as a scary army.
Name Nebuchadnezzar as a king of Babylon.
Identify Nineveh as the capital of Assyria.
Identify Babylon as a big, beautiful city.
Name Hammurabi as a king who made rules.
Identify Babylon's location on a map.
Identify Persia as a huge kingdom.
Name King Cyrus who let God's people go home.
Identify the Royal Road.
Identify Mesopotamia as the 'Land Between Rivers'.
Name the wheel and writing as things they invented.
Identify the 'Cradle of Civilization'.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Identify that the kingdom broke in two.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Name Israel (North) and Judah (South).

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Identify the prophets Elijah and Elisha.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Identify David as the shepherd king.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Name Solomon as the king who built the Temple.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Identify the Golden Age of Israel.
Identify that the big empire broke apart.
Name the Barbarians who attacked.
Identify Constantine (the first Christian emperor).
Identify Caesar Augustus as the first Emperor.
Name the Colosseum.
Identify Rome as a strong city.
Name the Senate as the group of leaders.
Identify the Consuls (two leaders).

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Recall God's promise to bless the whole world.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Observe them living in tents.
Recall that they had Emperors too.
Observe Chinese writing characters.
Recall that they lived here before Columbus.
Observe patterns in their art.
Recall that they took God's people away from their homes.
Observe the Ishtar Gate (blue bricks).
Recall that rules help people live together safely.
Observe a stone with writing on it (stele).
Recall that they used horses to send mail.
Observe that God uses kings to help His people.
Recall that Abraham came from a city here called Ur.
Observe pictures of Ziggurats (temple towers).

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Recall that bad kings made idols.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Observe that God sent prophets to warn them.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Recall that David loved God.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Observe Jerusalem as the special city.
Recall that nothing lasts forever but God.
Observe ruins of Roman buildings.
Recall that Rome built roads everywhere.
Observe gladiators and chariots.
Recall that they didn't want a king.
Observe the letters SPQR.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Summarize the journey from Ur to Haran to Canaan.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Explain the covenant: Land, Seed, Blessing.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Trace the 12 tribes back to Jacob's sons.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Explain the role of Joseph in preserving the family.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Defend the theological concept of Election.
Summarize the Shang and Zhou dynasties.
Explain the 'Mandate of Heaven'.
Explain the invention of paper and gunpowder.
Defend the continuity of Chinese civilization.
Summarize the Olmecs (giant heads).
Explain the Mayan calendar and math.
Explain the lack of large pack animals in the Americas.
Defend the complexity of these civilizations without Eurocentric bias.
Summarize the fall of Israel (to Assyria) and Judah (to Babylon).
Explain why these empires were called 'fierce'.
Explain the policy of deportation and exile.
Defend the fulfillment of prophecies concerning Nineveh and Babylon.
Identify the Pyramids and the Sphinx.
Name the Pharaoh as the king of Egypt.
Identify Hieroglyphs as picture writing.
Summarize the Code of Hammurabi ('Eye for an eye').
Explain why writing down laws is important.
Explain the role of the king as the guardian of justice.
Defend the superiority of biblical law regarding the value of life.
Summarize the story of Esther (Queen of Persia).
Explain how the Persians treated people nicely (tolerance).
Explain Zoroastrianism (religion of Persia).
Defend the biblical prophecy regarding Cyrus (Isaiah 45).
Summarize the geography of the Tigris and Euphrates valleys.
Explain what a City-State is (like Ur or Babylon).
Explain the significance of the 'Standard of Ur'.
Defend the biblical account of the origin of nations in this region.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Summarize the civil war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Explain why the North had no good kings.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Explain the Samaritan origin.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Defend the justice of the Exile.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Summarize the unification of the tribes under David.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Explain why Solomon was famous (wisdom and wealth).

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Explain the administration of the kingdom.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Defend the historicity of the United Monarchy (Tel Dan Stele).
Summarize why Rome got weak (too big, bad leaders).
Explain the split into West (Rome) and East (Constantinople).
Explain the survival of the Eastern (Byzantine) Empire.
Defend the concept of 'Transformation' rather than just 'Fall'.
Summarize the Pax Romana (Roman Peace).
Explain how roads and safe seas helped travel.
Identify Roman engineering (aqueducts, arches).
Explain the crisis of the third century.
Defend the benefits of Roman administration vs. local freedom.
Summarize the story of Romulus and Remus.
Explain what a Republic is (electing people).
Explain the role of the Tribune.
Defend the importance of the Rule of Law.
Identify a Greek soldier (Hoplite).
Name the Battle of Marathon (running).
Identify the Phalanx formation.
Identify Alexander as a young king who conquered the world.
Name his horse Bucephalus.
Identify the library of Alexandria.
Identify Greece as a land of islands and cities.
Name Athens as a city where people voted.
Identify Pericles as a great leader.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Compare the faith of Abraham with the scheming of Jacob.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Analyze the semi-nomadic lifestyle of the Patriarchs.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Interpret the significance of the birthright and blessing.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Connect the famine in Canaan to the move to Egypt.
Compare Confucius (respect) with Qin Shi Huang (power).
Interpret the significance of the Silk Road.
Connect the Great Wall to defense against nomads.
Compare the jungle cities with mountain cities (Andes).
Analyze the urban planning of Teotihuacan.
Interpret the collapse of the Classic Maya.
Connect the Chavin/Moche cultures to the later Incas.
Compare the Assyrian war machine with Babylonian culture.
Analyze the military tactics of the Assyrians (siege warfare).
Interpret the Hanging Gardens of Babylon (wonder of the world).
Connect the prophets (Isaiah, Jeremiah) to these political powers.
Recall that the Nile River was very important.
Observe mummies and painted coffins.
Compare Hammurabi's laws with God's laws (Ten Commandments).
Analyze the class distinctions in Hammurabi's Code.
Interpret the concept of 'Lex Talionis' (Law of Retaliation).
Connect Babylon to the later exile of Judah.
Compare the Persian rule with the Assyrian rule.
Analyze the administrative genius of Darius (Satraps).
Interpret the Cyrus Cylinder as historical evidence.
Connect the Persian Empire to the events of Ezra and Nehemiah.
Compare the life of a farmer in Sumer with a nomad.
Analyze the political structure of the first empires (Akkad/Sargon).
Interpret the religious worldview of polytheism in the ANE.
Connect the invention of Cuneiform to the preservation of history.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Compare the fate of Samaria (lost) vs. Jerusalem (exiled but returned).

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Analyze the geopolitical position of Israel between empires.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Interpret the 'Sin of Jeroboam' (false worship centers).

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Connect the Assyrian and Babylonian invasions to covenant curses.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Compare Saul (people's choice) with David (God's choice).

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Analyze the political consolidation of the kingdom.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Interpret the Davidic Covenant (2 Samuel 7) politically and theologically.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Connect Solomon's alliances to his spiritual downfall.
Compare the Fall of Rome with the start of the Middle Ages.
Analyze the internal vs. external causes of the fall.
Interpret the sacking of Rome (410 AD).
Connect the fall to the migration of Germanic tribes.
Compare Julius Caesar with Augustus.
Analyze the 'Bread and Circuses' policy.
Interpret the phrase 'All roads lead to Rome'.
Connect the stability of the empire to the spread of Christianity.
Compare the Patricians (rich) and Plebeians (regular).
Analyze the system of Checks and Balances in Rome.
Interpret the Twelve Tables (written law).
Connect the Punic Wars (Hannibal) to Rome's expansion.
Recall that the Greeks fought a huge empire.
Observe the 300 Spartans.
Recall that he spread Greek ideas everywhere.
Observe the huge map of his empire.
Recall that 'Democracy' means people decide.
Observe the Parthenon building.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Evaluate the cultural customs of the Middle Bronze Age.
Evaluate the civil service exam system.
Evaluate the sophistication of their astronomy.
Evaluate the role of these empires as 'the rod of God's anger'.
Summarize how the Nile flooding helped grow food.
Explain why they built Pyramids (tombs for the afterlife).
Explain the significance of the Rosetta Stone.
Defend the historicity of the Hebrew sojourn in Egypt.
Evaluate the justice system of Ancient Babylon.
Evaluate the strategy of religious toleration for empire stability.
Evaluate the 'hydraulic hypothesis' (irrigation leads to government).

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Evaluate the reforms of Hezekiah and Josiah.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Evaluate the tension between tribal independence and central monarchy.
Evaluate the economic factors (inflation, slavery).
Evaluate the moral decay of the empire.
Evaluate the causes of the Republic's collapse.
Summarize the story of the 300 at Thermopylae.
Explain how the small Greek navy won at Salamis.
Explain why Sparta won the civil war.
Defend the significance of the Greek victory for Western freedom.
Summarize Alexander's journey to India.
Explain what 'Hellenistic' means (Greek-like).
Explain the division of the empire after his death.
Defend the providential preparation of the world for the Gospel via Hellenism.
Summarize what a City-State (Polis) is.
Explain how voting worked in Athens (citizens only).
Explain the assembly and the ostracism.
Defend the legacy of Greek political thought in the West.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Construct a defense of the historical plausibility of the Patriarchal narratives.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Synthesize the Patriarchal history as the foundation of national identity.
Construct a comparison of the Han Dynasty and the Roman Empire.
Synthesize the impact of isolationism on China's history.
Construct a profile of pre-Columbian agriculture.
Synthesize the environmental factors in their development.
Construct a geopolitical map of the 8th-6th century BC.
Synthesize the cultural preservation achieved by the Library of Ashurbanipal.
Compare the Old, Middle, and New Kingdoms.
Analyze the social hierarchy of Egypt (Pharaoh as god-king).
Interpret the Book of the Dead and beliefs about the soul.
Connect Egyptian stability to its geography (desert protection).
Construct a comparative legal analysis of Mosaic Law vs. Hammurabi's Code.
Synthesize the rise of Babylon as a theological symbol in Scripture.
Construct a profile of the Achaemenid Empire's extent.
Synthesize the conflict between Persia and Greece (Marathon/Thermopylae).
Construct a timeline of the rise and fall of Sumerian and Akkadian power.
Synthesize the cultural legacy of Mesopotamia on later empires.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Construct a synchronized timeline of the kings of Israel and Judah.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Synthesize the prophetic message of judgment and hope.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Construct a map of the kingdom's expansion.

objectives.topic_name: Israel & Judah (The Story of Redemption in History)
objectives.objective_text: Synthesize the typology of the Kingdom of Israel.
Construct a critique of Gibbon's theory (Christianity weakened Rome).
Synthesize the legacy of Rome in the Western world.
Construct a map of the Empire at its height (Trajan).
Synthesize the legacy of Latin on European languages.
Construct a comparison of the Roman Republic and the American Republic.
Synthesize the transition from City-State to Empire.
Analyze the philosophy of Confucianism vs. Legalism.
Compare the Persian Wars (uniting) vs. Peloponnesian Wars (fighting each other).
Analyze the causes of the conflict between East and West.
Interpret the strategy of Themistocles.
Connect the Delian League to the rise of the Athenian Empire.
Compare the Greek language spreading with English today.
Analyze the military genius of Alexander.
Interpret the cultural fusion of East and West.
Compare Athens (thinkers) with Sparta (fighters).
Analyze the requirements for citizenship in Athens.
Interpret the Funeral Oration of Pericles.
Connect the geography of Greece to the independence of city-states.
Evaluate Thucydides' 'Trap' (rising power vs. ruling power).
Evaluate Alexander's character (hero or tyrant?).
Evaluate the exclusion of women and slaves in Greek democracy.
Construct a profile of a specific Pharaoh (e.g., Hatshepsut or Ramses II).
Synthesize the relationship between Egyptian religion and political power.
Construct a strategic analysis of a key battle.
Synthesize the destructive impact of the Peloponnesian War.
Connect the spread of Greek to the New Testament (Koine Greek).
Construct a profile of the Ptolemaic and Seleucid empires.
Synthesize the lasting cultural impact of the Hellenistic era.
Construct a critique of Direct Democracy (mob rule vs. republic).
Synthesize the rise and fall of the Athenian Golden Age.
Evaluate the architectural engineering of the Giza plateau.
